KMTEX, LLC 



RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN (RMP)



EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



KMTEX is committed to operating in a manner that is safe for KMTEX workers, the public and the environment.  As a part of this commitment, KMTEX has established a system to help ensure safe operation of the processes at this facility.  One part of this system is a risk management program (RMP) that helps manage the risks at KMTEX and that complies with the requirement of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) regulation 40 CFR part 68, Accidental Release Prevention Requirements; Risk Management Plan (the RMP rule).  One of the requirements of the RMP rule is to submit a risk management plan (RMPlan) describing the risk management program at KMTEX.  This document is intended to satisfy the RMPlan requirements of the RMP rule and to provide the public with a description of the RMP program at KMTEX in Port Arthur, Texas.



1.1 ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

KMTEX, LLC has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety and preservation of the environment. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, including training of personnel and safety in the design, installation, operation and maintenance of the processes at the KMTEX facility.  KMTEX implements controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances.  KMTEX places emphasis on prevention, prompt detection, and expeditious correction of unsafe conditions by periodically conducting internal inspection and regularly training responsible personnel. Should a release occur, the facility's trained personnel will respond to control, contain, and mitigate the release. 



1.2 KMTEX AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES



KMTEX may at times, handle sufficient quantities of a substance covered by the RMP rule. The substance covered under this rule is:



*Vinyl Acetate

ies.

1.3 GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



The following is a summary of the general accident prevention programs in place at the KMTEX facility in Port Arthur.  The KMTEX facility is an OSHA process safety management (PSM) regulated facility.  The elements of the KMTEX facility PSM program / OSHA PSM standard have been in place since 1991, which essentially mirror the prevention program requirement of the EPA's RMP standard. 



The accidental release prevention program required for Program 3 processes is summarized as follows:



Employee Participation



Active employee participation and involvement in the development and implementation of the facility's accident prevention program is a critical component of the overall objective to prevent or minimize the consequences of a catastrophic release of a flammable or toxic substance.  Employee involvement helps to ensure that all perspectives regarding accident prevention are considered for implementation.  Open communications are encouraged between supervisors and employees regarding all aspects of safety and health issues concerning employees, contractors and the public.  Employees are encouraged to participate in all facets of PSM and accident prevention.  Employee participation ranges from updating and compiling technical documents and chemical information to being a member of the Process Hazardous Analysis (PHA) team.  KMTEX strongly promotes employee involvement in safety issues through, for example, safety meetings, hazard communications, incident reporting systems and emergency response training.  Employees are encouraged to discuss accident prevention with their supervisors and to bring any questions, com

ments or suggestions forward for open discussion.



Process Safety Information (PSI)



Complete and accurate written process safety information concerning process chemicals, process technology and process equipment is essential to an effective accident prevention program, as well as completing and maintaining a PHA. The process safety information is readily available to all employees and used by facility personnel, the PHA team and persons in charge of updating the emergency response plan. KMTEX maintains a variety of technical documents that are used to maintain safe operations. These documents address chemical properties and associated hazards, limits for key process parameters, specific chemical inventories, equipment design basis and configuration. Chemical specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in Safety Data Sheets (SDS).



KMTEX also maintains numerous technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of process equipment at the facility. This information includes, but is not limited to, materials of construction, design pressure ratings, temperature ratings, and electrical rating of equipment. This information in combination with written procedures and trained personnel provides a basis for establishing inspection and maintenance activities.  This is also used for evaluating proposed process and facility changes to ensure that safety features in the process are not compromised.



Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)



The facility has a comprehensive program to ensure that hazards associated with the processes are identified and controlled. Within this program, the process is systematically examined to identify hazards and ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage these hazards.



KMTEX primarily uses the hazard and operability analysis (HAZOP) to perform these evaluations.  The analyses are conducted using a team of facility personnel who h

ave operating and maintenance experience as well as engineering expertise.  This team identifies and evaluates hazards of the process as well as accident prevention and mitigation measures. The team makes suggestions for additional prevention and/or mitigation measures when the team believes such measures are needed.  The PHA team findings and/or action items are forwarded to the appropriate personnel, addressed and tracked for completion.  Resolution of each finding is documented and records of the analyses are retained.



To ensure that the process controls and/or process hazards do not significantly deviate from the original design safety features, the facility periodically updates and re-validates the hazard analysis results. These periodic reviews are conducted at least every five years unless review is warranted sooner due to a significant change to the process. Once again, the reviews are documented and records of the review are retained.





Operating Procedures



KMTEX maintains written operating procedures in the form of runbooks at the facility that address various modes of process operations such as: (1) unit start-up, (2) normal operations, (3) temporary operations, (4) emergency shutdown, and (5) normal shutdown.  The operating procedures are reviewed by operators and technical staff before every process begins.  



Operating procedures provide current design and clearly written instructions for operating the processes. Instructions include applicable safety precautions and appropriate information on safety implications. Operating procedures ensure that all employees operate the processes in a prescribed, consistent, and safe manner. 



Training



To compliment the written procedures for process operations, KMTEX implemented a company training program for employees involved in operating a process.  New employees received basic training in KMTEX plant operations and are paired with a senior operator to learn process-specific duties and tasks.  Aft

er operators demonstrate (through test and skill demonstrations) having adequate knowledge to perform the duties and tasks in a safe manner on their own, they are deemed a "qualified" operator and can work independently.  All training is documented for each operator including the means to verify that the operator understood the training.



Contractors



KMTEX utilizes contractors during increased maintenance or construction activities. Because some contractors work on or near process equipment, KMTEX has mandated that all contractors attend and complete applicable training at the International Safety Training Council (ISTC) location to ensure that they: (1) perform their work in a safe manner, (2) have appropriate knowledge and skills, (3) are aware of the hazards at KMTEX, (4) understand what they should do in the event of an emergency, (5) understand and follow site-specific safety rules and, (6) inform KMTEX personnel of any hazards that they find while performing their work. This is accomplished by providing contractors with site specific training that covers: (1) a process overview, (2) information about the safety and health hazards, (3) emergency response plan requirements and, (4) safe work practices prior to beginning their work. In addition, KMTEX evaluates contractor safety programs, history and performance during the contractor selection process. KMTEX personnel monitor the contractor's performance to ensure that contractors are fulfilling their safety obligations.



Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR)



KMTEX conducts a Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR) on any new process or process modification that requires a change in process safety information. The purpose of the PSSR is to ensure that safety features, procedures, personnel, and equipment are appropriately prepared for startup prior to placing the equipment into service. This review provides an additional check that construction is in accordance with design specifications and that all supporting sys

tems are operationally ready. The PSSR involves field verification of the construction as per the piping and instrumentation diagram (P&ID) and serves as a quality assurance function by requiring verification that accident prevention program requirements are properly implemented.



Mechanical Integrity



KMTEX has practices and procedures to inspect/maintain tanks, pressure vessels, piping systems, relief and vent systems, controls, pumps, compressors and emergency response systems in a safe operating condition.  The basic aspects of this program include: (1) conducting training, (2) developing written procedures, (3) performing inspections and test, (4) correcting identified equipment deficiencies and, (5) applying quality assurance measures.

Written procedures help ensure that work is performed in a consistent manner and provide a basis for training.  Inspections and tests are performed to help ensure that equipment functions as intended and to verify that the equipment is within allowable limits.  If a deficiency is identified, employees will correct the deficiency before placing the equipment back into service or a Management of Change (MOC) will be distributed to appropriate personnel to review the use of the equipment and determine what actions are necessary to ensure the safe operation of the equipment. 



Safe Work Practices



KMTEX has safe work practices in place to help ensure worker and safety. Examples of these include: (1)

control of the entry/presence/exit of support personnel, (2) a lockout/tag-out procedure to ensure isolation of energy sources for equipment undergoing maintenance, (3) a procedure for safe removal of hazardous substances before process piping and equipment is opened, (4) a permit and procedure to control spark-producing activities (i.e., hot work) and, (5) a permit and procedure to ensure that adequate precautions are in place before entry into a confined space. These procedures, along with training of affected personnel, form

a system to ensure that operations and maintenance activities are performed safely at the facility.



Management of Change



KMTEX has a comprehensive system to manage change to the processes at the facility. Changes to process equipment, technology (including process operating conditions), procedures, changes to the quantity of regulated substances in the process, and other process changes are properly reviewed and authorized before being implemented. Reviews ensure that, (1) adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards and, (2) to verify that existing controls have not been compromised by the change. Safety Procedures, Environmental Procedures, Standard Operating Procedures, Operator Training, Maintenance Procedures, Maintenance Training, PSSR and P&ID drawings are reviewed and updated if necessary to incorporate these changes.  



Incident Investigation



KMTEX promptly investigates all incidents that result in, or reasonably could have resulted in, a fire/explosion, toxic gas release, major property damage, environmental loss, or personal injury. The goal of each investigation is to gather the facts, determine the root cause, and develop corrective action for the prevention of the same or a similar incident. The investigation team documents its findings and develops recommendations to prevent a recurrence.  The recommendations are forwarded to management for resolution, assigned to the appropriate department and tracked until the actions are complete. 



Compliance Audits



Compliance audits are conducted at least every three years.  Both hourly and management personnel may participate as audit team members and typically a third-party consultant is hired to assist in the audit.  The audit team develops findings that are forwarded to KMTEX facility management for resolution.  Corrective actions taken in response to the audit team's findings are tracked until complete.  The final resolution of each finding is documented and the two most recent r

This coordination includes periodic meetings of the Jefferson County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) and the Sabine Neches Chiefs Association (SNCA), which includes local emergency response officials, local government officials, and industry representatives. In addition to periodic LEPC meetings, KMTEX conducts emergency drills that involve the United States Coast Guard.  



1.6 PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



KMTEX strives to improve the safety of KMTEX processes through periodic safety reviews and the incident investigation program. KMTEX resolves all findings from PHA's, some of which result in modifications to the process.  KMTEX is continuously investigating and reviewing technology and/or applications that could possibly enhance its safety efforts. These currently include:



* Upgrade of Plant Firewater System

CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



Hazards in the KMTEX processes are continually managed to ensure safe operations. The existing safety features to prevent accidental releases of regulated substances in the facility are described below.



In addition to the accident prevention program activities, KMTEX has safety features on many units to help, (1) contain/control a release, (2) quickly detect a release and, (3) reduce the consequences or mitigate a release.  The following types of safety features are used in various processes. 



Release Detection



* Hydrocarbon detectors

* Process Alarms



Release Containment/Control



* Valves for safe isolation of the process (manual or automated)

* Automated shutdown systems for specific process parameters (I.E. high level, high temperature)

* Curbing or diking to contain liquid releases

* Redundant equipment and instrumentation (I.E. uninterruptible power supply for process control        

   system and redundant process control system and backup firewater pump

* Relief Devices        



1.4 FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



The KMTEX facility in Port Arthur has an excellent record of accident prevention. There have been no RMP incidents at the KMTEX facility in the past five years. The KMTEX facility has experienced no releases that resulted in deaths, injuries or significant property damage on-site or deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering-in-place, property damage or environmental damage off-site.  All incidents are investigated as per the severity and causes are identified and corrected.  The events that do not meet the EPA definition of an RMP incident, are investigated based upon severity level. 



1.5 EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
